pt: {sc}correct{/sc} {sc}accurate{/sc} {sc}exact{/sc} {sc}precise{/sc} {sc}nice{/sc} {sc}right{/sc} mean conforming to fact, standard, or truth. {sc}correct{/sc} usually implies freedom from fault or error.
{sc}accurate{/sc} implies fidelity to fact or truth attained by exercise of care.
{sc}exact{/sc} stresses a very strict agreement with fact, standard, or truth.
{sc}precise{/sc} adds to {sc}exact{/sc} an emphasis on sharpness of definition or delimitation.
{sc}nice{/sc} stresses great precision and delicacy of adjustment or discrimination.
{sc}right{/sc} is close to {sc}correct{/sc} but has a stronger positive emphasis on conformity to fact or truth rather than mere absence of error or fault.

et: Middle English, foolish, wanton, from Anglo-French, silly, simple, from Latin {it}nescius{/it} ignorant, from {it}nescire{/it} not to know {ma}{mat|nescience|}{/ma}

dt.t: They plan to fix up the place real {wi}nice{/wi}.
He still had his bald spots, but the fur that he did have cleaned up {wi}nice{/wi}.

In fact, the action is part of what made the findings redundant. The action mattered because it has, for the past two years, forced Microsoft to {phrase}play nice{/phrase}. {gloss}=to behave nicely; to be cooperative and unaggressive in dealing with others{/gloss}
Bipartisanship may also be elusive if it means a hostile GOP majority has to {wi}play nice{/wi} with a President it has tried to kick out of office.
